ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Magnetic and transport properties of electron-doped Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7

Affiliation.OrgName: Inner Mongolia Key Lab of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 with the nominal composition x=0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 is synthesized by solid-state reaction. The refined X-ray diffraction pattern of Ca2.807Bi0.193Mn2O7 with the nominal Bi3+ content x=0.2 indicates that about 71 % of the Bi3+ ion enters into the Ca2+ (2a) site and the remaining 29 % is in the Ca2+ (4e) site. The doped Bi3+ ion produces a ferromagnetic component in the antiferromagnetic matrix. Below the transition temperature, at about 110 K, the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions coexist. The alignment of the magnetic moment is canted at 5 K. The electric transport shows insulating behavior. Around the magnetic transition, at about 110 K, the resistance sharply drops like a well. A model proposed by Glazman and Matveev (GM model) is applied to the thermal variation of the resistance from 40 K to 138 K. Above this temperature, it is due to thermally activated hopping of small polarons with the activation energy of 50 meV. A negative magnetoresistance, 17 %, is observed with the doping content as low as 0.05. The magnetoresistance is due to the spin-polarized inelastic tunneling through nonmagnetic localized states embedded in an insulating barrier.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Ruddlesden–Popper (RP) compounds have received considerable attention due to their interesting magnetic and electrical properties, high-temperature superconductivity etc. [1–4]. The magnetoelectric effect is observed in Ca3Mn2O7 [5]. RP compounds (AO)(ABO3) n are built up with perovskite blocks (n layers of ABO3) separated by a rock-salt (AO) intermediary [6]. Many parent RP compounds are antiferromagnetic, and a certain amount of electron doping or strain induces magnetoresistance. Similar to CaMnO3, the series Ca n+1Mn n O3n+1 are antiferromagnetic with Néel temperatures around 110–130 K [7]. When single-electron-doped, the compounds Ca3−x La x Mn2O7 are antiferromagnetically canted below x≤0.3 and, above x≥0.4, the charge-ordering state appears [8]. Doping of Ca3Mn2O7 with tetravalent Th produces a significant ferromagnetic component in the magnetization at x=0.05, which diminishes with further increase of x and completely disappears at x=0.2. In Ca2.95Th0.05Mn2O7, a high magnetoresistance, −66 %, is observed [9]. The complex evolution of magnetic and transport properties is tuned with the composition in RP phases, partly due to mixed-valent Mn3+/Mn4+. Considering that Bi3+ has almost the same ionic size as Ca2+, this eliminates the chemical pressure effect and singles out the electron-doping effect in Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7. In this paper, we concentrate on the synthesis and properties of the single-electron-doped Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7. Since a layered structure in RP compounds provides them with the potential to develop an efficient low-field magnetoresistance, the transport behavior of Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 is studied.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para: Polycrystalline samples of Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 with the nominal composition x=0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 were prepared by solid-state reaction. By adding an excess of Bi2O3 (5 %) to compensate for subsequent mass loss, the starting materials CaCO3, Bi2O3 and (NH4)6Mo7O24⋅4H2O with proper weights were ground in an agate mortar, pressed into pellets, heated at 850 ∘C in air for 3 h and then heated at 1200 ∘C in air for 24 h three times. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out using a Rigaku D/max-2500 powder X-ray diffractometer with CuK α radiation. The diffraction data were collected for structure analysis, and the scan range 2θ was from 5∘ to 90∘, with a scanning step of 2θ= 0.014∘ and a sampling time 1 s. The magnetization was measured with a commercial Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer on pressed samples in the temperature range of 5–350 K. The transport measurements were performed on the same machine utilizing a standard four-probe technique with external device control.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The X-ray diffraction patterns show that the compounds with the nominal composition x≤0.3 crystallize in tetragonal structure with space group I4/mmm. Impurities are found in the compounds with x=0.5 and 0.7, and with x=0.9 it does not crystallize in the structure I4/mmm. Figure 1 shows the lattice parameters a and c. The lattice parameter a becomes longer and c becomes shorter as the Bi3+ ion increases. The X-ray diffraction pattern, as shown in Fig. 2, with the nominal composition Ca2.8Bi0.2Mn2O7, as a representative, is indexed by the Rietveld technique with the space group I4/mmm. The refined composition is Ca2.807Bi0.193Mn2O7, which is close to the nominal composition. The parameters obtained after the refinement converged are listed in Table 1. Almost 71 % of the Bi3+ ions substitute for Ca2+ at the 2b site, and the remaining 29 % of the Bi3+ ions enter into the Ca2+(4e) site. Table 2 shows the calculated Mn–O bond distances (angstroms) and Mn–O–Mn bond angles (degrees).

The dc magnetic measurements were carried out over a temperature range of 5–300 K at an applied magnetic field of 0.05 T at both zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) states, as shown in Fig. 3. At the ZFC state, the sample was cooled from room temperature down to 5 K at zero magnetic field, before measuring the magnetization (M) at an applied magnetic field of 0.05 T with the sample warming up to 300 K. At the FC state, the sample was first cooled from 300 K to 5 K under the magnetic field of 0.05 T. Then, M was measured in the warming process at the same field. At both ZFC and FC states, a magnetic transition is observed at about 130 K for x=0.05 and 0.1, and 120 K for x=0.2 and 0.3, as shown in the inset of Fig. 3. The sharp and singular step in the thermal magnetization indicates that the sample is magnetically single phased. When the temperature is lower than the transition temperature, the FC curve diverges from the ZFC curve, for all the compounds with x=0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3. The divergence indicates that the
Fig. 3
dc magnetic measurements with the nominal Bi content x=0.05 (squares), 0.1 (circles), 0.2 (up triangles) and 0.3 (down triangles) at 0.05 T at both ZFC (open) and FC (solid) states. The inset shows the corresponding derivative, dM/dT, at the FC state

positive and negative exchange interactions mixed together in a random-looking way, and the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions coexist below the transition temperature. The substitution of Bi3+ for Ca2+ introduces excess electrons in the lattice. The excess electrons in the compounds enable the coexistence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions, and the magnetic interaction is referred to as double exchange. Normally, the magnetic interaction due to double exchange is of ferromagnetic type. As a result, the long range magnetic ordering is induced in Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7, and takes the place of weak ferromagnetic interaction in Ca3Mn2O7 [10]. On the other hand, the electron in the itinerant e
g state in Mn4+ increases the Mn–O orbital overlap, which increases the size of the superexchange. Generally, the superexchange interaction favors an antiferromagnetic state. The superexchange and double exchange are simultaneously present in Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7, and give rise to the spin-glass-like state.

The applied magnetic field dependence of the magnetization at 5 K for all the series is shown in Fig. 4. The M(H) curves are hysteretic with a coercivity of 1000 Oe for x=0.2 and 0.3, and 200 Oe for x=0.05 and 0.1. M(H) is not saturated when the applied field is as high as 7 T. Considering that Bi3+ ions in Ca3Mn2O7 substitute Ca2+ in the perovskite layer CaMnO3, not entering into the rock-salt layer CaO, the evolution of the magnetic properties is comparable to CaMnO3. The doped electrons first induce ferromagnetic droplets embedded in the antiferromagnetic CaMnO3 matrix [11, 12]. With further electron doping, the long-range spin-canted phase appears [11, 12]. Similar to CaMnO3, the addition of Bi3+ ions in Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 induces the long-range spin-canted phase, and it affords the unsaturated magnetization. The magnetization of Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7, at 50 kOe, is 0.28 emu/g. When the Bi3+ content is x=0.1 and 0.2, the magnetization is 0.25 and 0.22 emu/g, respectively. When the Bi3+ content is 0.3, the magnetization decreases to 0.08 emu/g. It is comparable with the electron-doping effect in Ca3−x Th x Mn2O7 [9]. Its highest magnetic moment is at the Th4+ content x=0.05, and decreases with further Th4+ substitution.
Fig. 4
The magnetization versus the magnetic field of Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 with the nominal Bi3+ content x=0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 at 5 K

The resistance of Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7 versus temperature at the magnetic fields of H=0 and 70 kOe is shown in Fig. 5. The resistance decreases with increasing temperature. It exhibits three distinct regimes, at high, middle (close to magnetic phase transition) and low temperatures. The temperature dependence is different in each regime. At low temperature, the resistance versus temperature can be fitted with the model, proposed by Glazman and Matveev (GM model) [13], which deals with inelastic tunneling in disordered materials. In this model, carriers lose phase memory in the process of hopping along paths with localized states. According to the GM model, the temperature dependence of the conductance is given by
$$G = (G_{0} + G_{1}) + \sum_{n = 2}^{\infty} b_{n}T^{n - 2/n + 1} $$ for eV≪k
B
T, i.e.
$\rho \propto \sum_{n = 2}^{\infty} a_{n}T^{ - (n - 2/n + 1)}$ . The summation term describes the temperature-dependent inelastic multistep tunneling via n≥2 localized states. When n=2, the power index is 4/3; when n=3, it is 5/2. The index 4/3 signals the inelastic tunneling across a thin film via two localized states. The experimental (thin dotted line) and the calculated resistance variations (thick colored line) by the GM model at 0 Oe are shown in Fig. 5. At very low temperature, the calculated data with n=1.3 deviates from the measured data and, at slightly higher temperature, the calculation reflects the experimental variation. When the temperature increases to about 40 K, the index n in the model is 5.56. Between 98 K to 138 K, the resistance sharply decreases like a well, as shown in the inset of Fig. 5. Considering that the temperature is around the magnetic transition, the peculiar resistance variation is assumed to be related with the change of the magnetic state. It suggests that the electric transport is sensitive to the magnetic field. While fitting with the GM model, the indexes are 12.0 and 26.9, between 98 K and 138 K. As the temperature and n further increase, the transport develops into small-polaron transport. The charge transport via activated hopping of small polarons follows R=R 0 Texp(−E a/k B T), where R 0 is a temperature-independent constant, E a is the hopping activation energy and k is the Boltzmann constant [14]. The fitted E a is 50 meV. E a is associated with the insulating phase and correlated with the electron delocalization.
Fig. 5
The resistance of Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7 versus temperature at the magnetic fields of H=0 (thick black solid line) and 70 kOe (thin red broken line). The inset shows the corresponding enlargement around 90 K to 145 K

The x=0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 samples exhibit negative magnetoresistance (MR), at low temperature, as shown in the inset of Fig. 5 for Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7 as an example. The maximum MR value is observed in the sample with x=0.05. The ratio, (R(H)−R(0))/R(0), is about −15 % at 70 kOe, as shown in Fig. 7. MR is negative below 26 K, and then become positive up to 62 K. The resistance difference ΔR decreases from 5 K to 36 K, and increases from 36 K to 62 K. The extension of the GM model is used to account for the magnetoresistance. The magnetoresistance is nearly proportional to the square of the magnetic field, as shown in the inset of Fig. 6. This suggests that it is tunneling-effect-related. The spin-polarized inelastic tunneling occurs through nonmagnetic localized states embedded in an insulating barrier [15]. According to Lu et al. [15], the tunneling magnetoresistance (MR) gradually decreases with the index n even for spin-conserving channels. It is consistent with the experiments. The fast decrease of ΔR in the range of 5 K to 36 K is consistent with the thermally activated spin-dependent inelastic tunneling MR process. The positive MR from 26 K up to 62 K is possibly due to the quantum electron–electron interaction [16].
Fig. 6
The experimental resistance variation (thin dotted line) and the resistance variation calculated by the GM model (thick colored line) at 0 Oe. The inset shows the ratio (R(H)−R(0))/R(0) of Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7 versus the temperature at 70 kOe
Fig. 7
The magnetoresistance of Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7. The inset shows the magnetoresistance versus the magnetic field

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Bi3+-doped Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7 was synthesized by solid-state reaction. The refined X-ray diffraction pattern of the nominal Ca2.8Bi0.2Mn2O7 indicates that it is Ca2.807Bi0.193Mn2O7. About 71 % of the Bi3+ ion enters into the Ca2+ (2a) site and the remaining 29 % is in the Ca2+ (4e) site. The Mn–O bond distance and the Mn–O–Mn bond angle were calculated. The doped Bi3+ ions induce a significant ferromagnetic component, as evidenced by the divergence between the ZFC and the FC curves. The electron doping first induces ferromagnetic droplets embedded in the antiferromagnetic matrix, and then induces a long-range spin-canted phase. The electric transport is insulating. The repeated measurements showed that the resistance sharply dropped around the magnetic transition, at about 110 K. From 40 K to about 138 K, the transport mechanism is simulated by the GM model, showing an inelastic tunneling in disordered materials. The magnetoresistance is observed in Ca3−x Bi x Mn2O7. It is about −17 % at 70 kOe and 5 K for Ca2.95Bi0.05Mn2O7.
